instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-01521: What is 820-01521? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.A1932: What is A1932? A1932 is a model number for a 13 inch size MacBook Air from years Late 2018, 2019 with EMC 3184, that may contain one of these boards depending on the year & configuration: 820-01521..
definitions.U7000: What is U7000? U7000 refers to the ISL6258 or ISL6259 charging IC on Macbooks from 2008-2012.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.PP3V3_G3H_RTC: What is PP3V3_G3H_RTC? PP3V3_G3H_RTC Is one of the first rails that has to come on in order for the USB-C mux chip to be powered in the T2 chip Macbook Pros..
definitions.PPVBAT_G3H_CONN: What is PPVBAT_G3H_CONN? This is the where the batteryâ€™s power rail connects to the motherboard. .
definitions.PP20V_USBC_XB_VBUS: What is PP20V_USBC_XB_VBUS? PP20V_USBC_XB_VBUS is 20v in from the USB-C charger on USB-C powered Macbook Pros..
definitions.PP1V8_SLPS2R: What is PP1V8_SLPS2R? PP1V8_SLPS2R is a 1.8v power rail present when the system is in a SLPS2R state. .
definitions.PP1V1_SLPS2R: What is PP1V1_SLPS2R? The PP1V1_SLPS2R power rail in the MacBook schematic provides a 1.1-volt supply in a specific low-power state indicated by the "_SLPS2R" suffix and is used for powering the T2 chip..
definitions.PP1V2_AWAKE: What is PP1V2_AWAKE? The PP1V2_AWAKE signal in the MacBook schematic is a power rail that provides 1.2 volts and is associated with the machine's awake state and is used for powering the T2 chip..
definitions.820-01987: What is 820-01987? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01521</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A No  Power
threads.message:
<MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1932</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> Macbook Air with water damage to the Audio board area.

Audio board was completely damaged therefore was replaced with a new one, macbook also had some water damage on the battery connector and nearby area but battery is fine and not shorts on capacitor <CAPACITOR>C8469</CAPACITOR>) or diode (<DIODE>D8410</DIODE>)

USB Meter shows 5.2V and 0.21Amps on <SIGNAL>PP20V_USBC_XA_VBUS</SIGNAL> (Current drops zero and loops)
USB Meter shows 5.2V and 0.21Amps on <SIGNAL>PP20V_USBC_XA_VBUS</SIGNAL> (Current drops zero and loops)

Voltages
<SIGNAL>PP20V_USBC_XA_VBUS</SIGNAL> = 5v
<SIGNAL>PP20V_USBC_XB_VBUS</SIGNAL> = 5v
<SIGNAL>PP20V_USBC_XB_V</SIGNAL> = 5v
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H_RTC</SIGNAL> = 3.2v
<SIGNAL>CHGR_EN_MVR</SIGNAL> = 5V
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> = 12.31v

No Short on F3000 or F3010 or F7000

<TRANSISTOR>Q7065</TRANSISTOR> Voltages
Source Pin 1,2,3 = 12.32v
Gate Pin 4 = 12.31v
Drain Pin 5,6,7,8 = 0.22v

Voltages at Fuse F7000 (On Charger going through <TRANSISTOR>Q7065</TRANSISTOR>)

Pin 1 = 0.22 (<SIGNAL>PPVBAT_G3H_CONN</SIGNAL>)
Pin 2 =0.22 (<SIGNAL>PPVBAT_G3H_CONN</SIGNAL>)

Voltages at Fuse F7000 (on Battery)
Pin 1 =1.31
Pin 2 =1.21

Coils
No short to ground on any coils
5VPWM = 0.01v
3VPWM = 3.24v
Up and Down inductor = 5.1


I assume <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> needs to be created first at a voltage of 12.6 - 1305 volts before the CD32 work? or do I have an issue with the <CHIP>U7000</CHIP> ISL9240HI? Could the Audio Board water damaged caused damaged to the main board and if so what area (T2 Chip?)

Diode Mode  to ground 
Pin 32  = OL
Pin 33  =  0.99KOhms

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01521</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A No  Power
threads.message:
I don't understand why do you insist with F7000.
This board can start without battery, just with charger.
Is the first step to do; getting it turned on with charger alone.
In such case, fan will start with high speed, because of missing battery; just a secondary issue.

You should check the other T2 lines to ground; the ones corrsponding to J6100.
Personally I bet for dead T2.
Can you put the machine in DFU?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01521</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A No  Power
threads.message:
" I don't understand why do you insist with F7000. "
I am  referencing F7000 because when the Charger is in (Without battery) I would measure at F7000 Pin 1 to see if it is getting the 12.69 voltage which it does not. 

I will  check DFU mode but  won't this wipe the customers data ? Which other  T2  Lines are to  ground.

Please  also not I am learning  so please don't assume I know  everything.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01521</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A No  Power
threads.message:
Why do you expect F7000 voltage without battery???
F7000 is not placed on <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>, like other boards.
In my first post I did the same mistake, responding without checking the correct schematic.

DFU revive will not erase internal SSD.
If you have important information, do NOT choose restore option!
However, if T2 results to be dead, the SSD information is also lost.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01521</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A No  Power
threads.message: DFU Mode  does not work, what else can I do to confirm the T2  Chip is at fault here?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01521</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A No  Power
threads.message:
Did you exactly follow all the steps in the tutorial linked on the forum?
Check if all AWAKE and SLPS2R voltages are present.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01521</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A No  Power
threads.message:
I have done  a  DFU repair  before on a Macbook so I am certain it is not working and I have done the correct steps. Will replacing the T2 Chip fix the laptop and does that mean the customer data would have to be wiped.

<SIGNAL>PPVDDCPU_AWAKE</SIGNAL> =0.75v (boot loops  between 0 and 0.75v)
PPVDDCPUSRAM_AWAKE =0.8v (boot loops between 0 and 0.8v)
<SIGNAL>PP1V8_SLPS2R</SIGNAL> = (boot loops between 0 and 1.8v)
<SIGNAL>PP1V1_SLPS2R</SIGNAL> = 1.1v (Constant voltage)
<SIGNAL>PP0V8_SLPS2R</SIGNAL> = 0.8v (Constant voltage)
<SIGNAL>PP1V2_AWAKE</SIGNAL> = 1.2v (Constant voltage)
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_AWAKE</SIGNAL> =0.89v  (Constant voltage)

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01521</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A No  Power
threads.message: Very likely T2 was damaged by liquid spill on audio board...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01521</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A No  Power
threads.message: so I can replace the T2 IC to get  it working again, but I assume it would wipe the customers data?

threads.message:
